OK. Amazing. Can everybody hear me? Yeah. Thanks so much. Mark, it was great having you in
my qualifying exam, in which I

presented one just
vague origami box. We're going to study this cube
from a mathematical standpoint.

And I will say, not much has
changed, except this time we're going to talk
about even more cubes, but maybe a little
bit on a high level.

So I realize we've got a great
crew here today of roboticists. This is a bit more on
the computational origami

perspective. But we want to know how can
we apply new design techniques into robotics applications.

And also maybe this will
help spark your curiosity and start thinking
about new creative ways to implement novel mechanical
mechanisms in order

to address some traditionally,
maybe, electronic or computational challenges. And here's, just to give
a little bit of a teaser,
here's an example of-- this is an origami hand.

And you can see they're all made
out of the same origami cube. And if you look at
your hand, you'll

see that your hand
is what's called under-actuated mechanisms. So it's not like
you're thinking, oh, I'm having a bunch of
different joints in my hand.

I'm just going to
activate all my joints. You just go like this
and you can easily get that grasping
motion without thinking

about each individual joint. And you guys also might
be familiar with origami.

And you know that there's a
lot of emergent properties that comes from, basically, just
placing a bunch of creases

onto an origami sheet. And then there's literally
millions, if you go online,

literally millions of
different types of origami that you can fold, and
also interesting mechanical

properties that can
be utilized to a lot of different engineering
applications, whether that's in
metamaterials or trying

to create these highly
coupled structures to get interesting motion out of them. So what we're going to do
here is, instead of folding

with sheet origami,
which is typical, what about cubic origami? Now you can see this is a big
design challenge because all

of the sides are sealed up. So it's going to have a lot
of constraints to the system. And it's entirely
a convex polyhedra.

And, I guess, for a little
bit of audience participation, we'll have a few
people in the audience

be some representatives
for the waterbomb base. So this is actually a very
ancient origami design

that's kids like to fold these
little waterbomb cubes out of origami, and
then play with them and toss them around as balls.

But they also fold
completely flat. So this is what it looks like
when it's-- with all the of it open. And here's when it's flat.

Does anybody want to be
the representatives today? It's like-- OK.

Maybe somebody over here-- We've got even more cubes. So you guys will be the
representatives for today

for the waterbomb base. You'll see it's actually
quite challenging to compress all the way
because it causes a lot.

You might even tear
the cube by accident when you're trying to do it. Actually, there's
some similar issue

with what's called the
square cresting unit. So it goes here, and it
folds all the way flat.

As you can see, this also-- Who wants to be
the representative? Do you want to get it? You can see it's actually very,
very difficult to fold it flat.

In fact, some might
even say impossible, without tearing the paper. And that's why there's
a very common use called

modified cresting. So you actually pull
out some of the space. See how the unit here
has some space removed,

that allows you to
do the same motion but without tearing the paper. So we've got a good number of
examples of the cresting unit.

Anybody want to be
representatives? We've got four units. So you can see here,
we're able to--
and get some people in the back.  Basically, it's a 1D path.

But it'll fold all the way. And then today, we're
going to also introduce some four new foldable
cubes, one of them

the sawhorse molecule. So we place this on the side,
and then it can become a cube.

And then we can also get some
roll, pitch, and yaw angles. We've also got a
minimal slit cut.

So we're cutting a
very, very tiny slit in the corner of the cube. We've got the
octahedral unit cell.

So this is like a cuboid. So you can connect it to
each other on a lattice. When you connect a lot
of them on a lattice,

then you can get an interesting
metamaterial property. And then finally a
generalized cuboid-- so this has the most number
of creases in the cube.

And depending on where you place
it, you can get six DOF motion. You can pretty much change
it in all kinds of skew ways.

So we've got a few
more blocks here. Oh, and the one I
forgot to mention, also, is a cube that has
a diagonal slit across.

So, then, you can fold
that flat as well. It's also rigidly foldable. So if you guys want
to pass that around?

Get some representatives
to hold the cube. And ideally, everybody
here in the center will have be been
able to hold a cube.

As you can see, here's
eight different cubes. They've got a lot of
different emergent properties. And I think this is just to
try to spark your imagination

and say, what other
kinds of cubes could we even make if we change the
position of different creases on the surface.

And this is just the same
principle as regular origami. We're going to place
creases on the surface and then just see what kind
of emergent behavior occurs.

So our goal here is
we want to combine the mathematical elegance
and the creative design of these foldable cubes with
a practical functionality

for robots. And I think you might be
asking the question, OK, so what is
mathematical elegance? Is that just like mathematical?

Many students say that,
oh, we like something. Oh, it's such an
elegant solution. And the short answer is yes.

But there's also a lot
of ways that we can dive into this concept of elegance. And then also, secondly, what
about practical functionality?

You guys are all holding
different cubes right now. And you're going to go to your
neighbor and be like, oh, yeah, my cube is better than
yours because of--

and then fill in
the blank there. What is going to be
a more useful cube? What is going to be the
not that useful cube,

just in general without
diving down into saying, OK, we have a
specific application.

What kind of robot do we need
to address this application? So one of the things that we can
talk about is modular robotics.

So one approach is
intra-reconfigurability. You don't change
anything with the cubes. And you adjust their position
with respect to one another.

And the other one is-- actually, this is an example
from the previous paper electro

voxels. They do a ton of
different steps, where they move the cubes with
respect to one another

to get the chair that
converts into a couch. And what we're going to
be talking about today

is inter-reconfigurability. So you keep the same position
of the chair with respect to each other.

And then you can get this
motion in a lot fewer DOF.

So here's an audience
participation. So I know you guys are all
holding cubes right now. Anybody want to
hold up your cube,

if you think that
your cube could be used to achieve
this reconfiguration? Anybody?

We've got one back here. I think that is
the right answer.

My eyesight is not
quite good enough. But it is the octahedral unit
and the generalized cuboid. And that's because those
are able to undergo

the reconfiguration in
order to achieve this. If you were to use
that block to represent

one of those yellow cubes, you
would be able to make that. And this speaks to one of
the fundamental properties.

And today, we're
going to just give you a primer of what kind of
fundamental properties of origami cubes are
considered useful

and then what are we
interested in studying when we look at a cube. And one of that is
the range space. So can the cube--

what shapes can it be made into? Can it do roll, pitch, and yaw? Can it re-configure
in multiple ways or have one path of motion
that's the range space?

Another one is flat foldability. So in 2D origami, there's a very
popular theorem that's called the Meakawa Kawasaki theorem.

It basically says that if you
look at the alternating angles, they should sum
to 0, and then you can fold the paper
completely flat.

So you just look at the
angles, see if they sum to 0. But it's actually a bit more
complicated in cube origami because you've got these
90-degree angle faces.

So when they start to
compress they can self lock. They'll intersect
with each other. And there's not really a great
deterministic mathematical

method to see if it's
going to do that. But that's actually a
very interesting property when it comes to robotics,
because we might sometimes

want a self-locking property. Let's say we want it to self
lock into a roll, pitch, or yaw configuration,
that's actually

quite great for designing
in this without having your motor be like, oh, I
have to actuate and hold

this position if that's
the final end state. So here's another
audience participation.

Anybody want to hold
up your cube if you think that it's flat foldable? So can it fold completely flat. We've got a lot of
cubes in the room.

Looks great. And yes, most of the
cubes are flat foldable. And Additionally, we've got two
cubes, the sawhorse molecule

and the generalized cuboid,
that are not flat foldable. So even if you pushed it, you
would start to rip the paper

and start to reduce the
structural integrity because it's got that
self-locking capability without going all the way flat.

So here's another
property we want to know if it's flat,
foldable or self-locking. And then finally, we've
got multistability.

So I don't know if you've
ever heard of a Venus flytrap. But it's a carnivorous plant. And most plants aren't
known for attacking stuff.

So they don't want to
use a lot of energy. And they're just kind
of sitting there. And then they've got a
multistable mechanism that's

like a curve that
goes from out to in. and Then it'll snap
to close on the fly.

And that's similar to how
this merging property happens in a lot of these cubes
is because you have

to input an energy barrier. And then it's got these two
stable end configurations. So as you can see,
like the Venus flytrap,

you might be able to save
energy if you're applying it to a robotic situation,
maybe with a soft actuator,

where you don't want to use
too much actuation energy, you just want it to toggle
between these two end

configurations. So audience
participation-- anybody have a cube that you think
might be a multistable cube?

Yes, we got enthusiastic
in the back. Anybody else have
a multistable cube?

So these are all multistable,
even though some of them are pretty difficult to actuate. The reason why they're
difficult to actuate

is because they have such
a high energetic barrier. You almost have to really
fold the cube in order

to get it to actuate. So this is our final
property, rigid foldability

versus multi stability. If it's rigidly foldable all
the sheets don't have to fold,

or you don't have to
have an angle in them. It can do it completely rigid. So basically here we've got
a toolkit of origami cubes.

I'm not trying to say
like, oh, rigidly foldable versus multistable, which
one is better than the other? It, really, is a toolkit.

And it has to do with
what kind of properties that you want to have. But what we really want to
do is expand the toolkit

and also understand some
of these properties. Does anybody have a
time-- oh, it's up here. OK. Amazing.

I don't want to run out. So, I guess, I'll go through
just briefly a few of these.

This is not the
full contribution. If you're interested,
you can read the paper and try to dive in
a little bit more.

But I'll just show
a couple of things that I thought was cool about
each of these different cubes.

And I think they're definitely
different in properties. But we'll start off with
talking about the sawhorse.

So just to jog your memory, this
is the video from beginning. You can see that they're all
made out of the same cube.

And we also did a
couple different-- here's some other demos. For example, we have a
concave and convex surface

that toggles in
between each other, as well as showing an
alternating zigzag lattice.

But you can see
here, they're all made out of different
embodiments of the same cube.

So as you can see here, we've
got the multistable effect. We can do roll, pitch, and yaw. And we can also do
tunable joint limits.

So when you push
down on the cube, even push down a little
bit, or it can really compress all the way down.

And actually, one interesting
thing to point out is that the sawhorse
decomposes into other cubes.

So we've got the sawhorse. You can place these vertices
anywhere within this region. It really is a topology
that shows how they're

connected to each other. But if you put them all
the way in the corners, you got the modified
crystalline, which I think some people-- it's
the block that doesn't compress.

Somebody here has
the crystalline. Or you can put the vertices
and combine them to the center,

and then they actually
become the waterbomb, which is the sixth
vertex in the center. So you have these
decompositions.

And in this way, we
call this a molecule, because it's the general
topological space

of a specific embodiment,
which is the unit cell. So you basically put the
vertices in a certain location,

and then you've got
a different property. We did a couple
different models of this. Thin, deformable panels--
so this is a 2D model,

but also thick, rigid panels. Thick origami is
actually a huge challenge because when it starts
to bend, and they

intersect with each
other in a weird way, so you have to tailor
in gaps to the model.

And OK, now, I guess, we have
a game here, higher or lower? So we talked a little bit
about the energetic barrier.

It's kind of how difficult
it is to compress or how much energy do you
have to put in the system. So if you have a
motor on your robot,

you have to put a big
motor, or do you only have to add a teeny tiny
motor that easily just adds

a little bit of force? I like when audiences say things
together, because it's funny.

Stiff hinges or
less stiff hinges, which will give a higher
energetic barrier? Stiff edges. Yeah.

How about rigid panels
versus less rigid panels? Rigid panels. Yeah, rigid panels.

And how about stretchy hinges
versus not stretchy but flexible hinges?

I actually don't
like flexible hinges. OK. This was actually
a trick question. And that was actually a
pretty interesting finding

of our study. We looked at the face material
and the hinge material and seed and looked at do we want to have
flex rigid or flexible, stretchy

or non stretchy. And then we created mathematical
models for both of them in order to accommodate both
the amount of face bending,

as well as the amount of
hinge bending in the model to see if we could
sum them up to predict

what kind of energetic
curve that we would get. So for face bending, we have
rigid versus flexible hinge.

You can see,
interestingly enough, the non-stretch is
like a linear curve, whereas the stretchy hinge, we
modeled as an exponential curve.

And this ended up being what we
saw in the experimental results that in the small
displacement region,

then the contribution of the
stretchy hinges isn't as much. But as you start to really push
the limits of your displacement,

then you really see a
strong component taking over of that flexible part.

Here's another question that
has to do with the geometry. So not the materials, just
the geometry of the block.

Which one causes a higher
energetic better barrier, more twist or less twist?

More twist. Yes, more twists. You can see it
starts to decompose towards the crystalline unit.

How about a larger range
versus a smaller range, that's the H parameter? Larger range.

Yeah, larger range. And you can, interestingly, see
that the higher the H parameter,

the more energy dissipation
you also see for the voxels. And if you were to change
them all into the line,

you can see that when you apply
a constant force from the top, first the orange block buckles,
then the yellow block, then

the light blue block, then
the next lightest blue block, then the most next
lightest blue block. It all goes in the order of
overcoming these energy barriers
that get subsequently larger. And here's another thing.

Hold up the block if you think
yours has the lowest energy barrier of anybody in the room? So this is a person
who's been playing

with their block the whole
time of the presentation. Yeah, that one definitely does
have a very low-energy barrier.

And that's also something
that we found in our studies, is that the more that
you cycle the block-- If you have a paper block,
then you can cycle it.

But then after around 200
cycles, it starts to even out. So it really shows there's
also a material degradation

property in addition to just the
geometric and the fundamental material parameters.

Now, I'll give a brief
overview of some work

in adding a minimal
slit to the block. So here's an audience
memory test from earlier.

So you can hold up your
block if it was geometrically multistable from earlier. Yeah, we have a lot of
multistable blocks here.

They're not rigidly foldable. And now, how about if your
block is completely closed,

your block has no cuts
or openings in it. Yeah, it's the same
group of people. So I wonder why that is.

Well, that was shown
in 1813 by Cauchy, who proved that convex
polyhedra that are constructed

of rigid faces and hinged edges
are in and of themselves rigid. And even if you
add finitely-- you

add so many different
creases to it, it'll still be rigidly foldable. However, Abel, in
2014, was able to show

that if you cut the surface,
it will remove this property. And we can add a
minimal cut size

in order to rigidly
flatten a tetrahedron. So the way we do this is
we add a teeny tiny cut.

And then somehow, we are
able to completely remove this super-large energy
barrier that we previously had,

by making the minimal small cut. So I think somebody here
has the diagonal cut block that has a really
large cut that goes

all the way across the face. What if we-- that's right. Right here, we've got the
big diagonal cut block.

What if we made one that
has a super small cut block? So we basically start with
the traditional water bomb,

make it rotationally
symmetric, and then we add a few different
cuts and creases.

And the methodology
that we use for this is parametrizing the cube. We solve for the
minimum cut size.

And we find that it's
8.6% of the edge length. So that's a super-small
cut compared to the size of the edge
length, and much smaller

than the large diagonal. So this is just a
computational equivalent

to the analytic model,
which is the minimal length. Here it's too short. Here it's too long.

So just right is the size of the
cut that is basically able to--

when you fold the
block, it'll be equal to the original distance
between the end points. So you don't try
to start folding it

and then you separate it more
than you originally started out to. Another corollary to this
is changing the number

of cuts in each cube. Can we do a programmable
multistability? So instead of having
all four cuts,

what if we do one
or two or three? And this also has
a similar effect,

in that we're able to reduce
the energetic barrier by adding more and more cuts to the
block, until you finally

have the all four cuts,
which is both theoretically, rigidly foldable, and it's also
shown in the experiment as well.

And finally, I'll
talk about what happens when you combine
multiple of these blocks together.

And one of the great
examples of this is the octahedral unit
cell, because that is the one that has multiple
equal ways of reconfiguration.

And it also has
this stiffness to it that prevents you from
collapsing it entirely.

So we want to know how the
individual units reconfigure and then also how they create
tessellations together.

So in terms of how they
individually reconfigure, there's basically
three pathways. You can compress it
in the x direction.

You can compress it
in the y direction. And you can compress it all the
way down in the z direction. But because there's an internal
structure, what you can't do

is push all of the
corners together. It would make something that
doesn't have a lot of rigidity.

And we want to
really enforce like-- OK, here are the
x, y, z pathways. Those are the only pathways
that you can follow.

And we do need to have a
kinematic model for this if we're going to
do the next step and put it into the
generative model

to create the tessellations. But it's actually a
little bit challenging. And the reason why
it's challenging is because if you
have a height h, then

you can have more
than one states. So for example here, we've got-- let's say, we have h equals 2.

Then it could be
completely flat, or it could be
rotationally symmetric. So it just makes it a
very complicated system

to try to solve. But here's just a random idea
that seems completely unrelated, which is looking at the
geometry of a sphere passing

through a plane. When you have a sphere. It passes through the plane. There's a circle that is
formed at the intersection.

And the circle gets bigger and
smaller, not in a linear way, but in a way that's proportional
to the geometry of the circle.

And we can use that
exact same geometry in order to solve this system,
because if we place the four

corners of the cube and we
place at the intersecting plane,

and we place the A vertex
at the center of the sphere, we can actually get exactly
the same system when

the block moves around. And then this also
allows us to satisfy the property of
making that tube shape

and making a center
shape, because we can move the position
of the C vertices around that intersecting circle.

So this is like I just
showed a lot of math. But I think it just
goes to show how when you're trying to
characterize these systems,

there might be some interesting
and surprising analogs that you can use in order to try to
understand how this very, very

coupled geometry can distill
down into something that's more simple. And we also did some
generative modeling, which

I won't get into too deep with. But here's just a few
different tessellations that have different properties.

So this one can compress
in all three directions. This one is fully rigid. If you push on it, it's
completely incompressible.

And this one has a really
weird folding method, where it folds in one
direction, which is like this.

So it's this structure. But then when it folds flat,
it can only go one way. And it's like
[MAKES WHOOSHING SOUND].

So I think, it's just a
very interesting example of how you can create
these generative models,

and then sometimes have
a surprising result. So, OK, what's next here? We talked about three
different cubes.

We have sawhorse, minimal slit,
octahedral, and briefly touched on a few other funding work.

One, I think, big vision is
a pretty large challenge, which is a 3D
shape-matching problem.

So if you want to
create a robot that is able to do shape shifting,
we say, oh, here's one shape,

here's another shape,
and we want both of those shapes to be energetically
minimal, then,

I think this is one
potential pathway, just because it's a
super coupled system. And I think another big vision
that we can start to dream of

is-- this is a paper from 2013
from Hod Lipson lab called Evolutionary design of robots.

And they completely created
these running robots just out of cubes. And this was using an
evolutionary algorithm,

where each of these cubes
had a different property. So if we have even
more tailored cubes, you could just imagine how
this evolutionary design,

a very complicated systems,
could start to take hold. So thank you so much
for coming today.
[APPLAUSE]

And we have six more
minutes for questions.

I have a question. I'm very curious about the-- you basically provide
a different way to consider the construction
of robotic structures.

One thing I'm especially curious
is in the last modular design, where you have one shape
and repeat it for many times

to build a larger structure that
can move and show some macro

behavior. I wonder how's [AUDIO OUT]
damage on some of the models.

Some of them are-- that we also
ran here are the robot got hit,

or some part of the
body is damaged,

would the overall deterioration
inside of that part. Yeah. That's a really good question,
because that was actually

one part that we did incorporate
into our model, which is looking at the number of
points of connectivity

from one block to another. So we had a block. And we could have different
degrees of rotation. But as you can--

it's hard to visualize
without the visual. But basically, when you
have two blocks together. You might have one that only
has a few points of connection.

And that's not a very
strong connection. Whereas if you actually put a
90-degree rotation to connect

them, it's very strong. So if you look at the total
number of points of connection of each individual
block, you can use it

as a proxy to see if it's a
very rigid structure or one that's not. And we also just
threw out ones that we

thought, OK, this is just not
enough points of connection. It's not going to be
structurally stable enough.

Oh I see. Yeah. Thanks. That's a great question. How difficult is the control of
those big robots when you make

with a bunch of origami cubes? I think one of the
goals for control is to do it in as few
actuators as possible.

So one way that we
can do that is-- for a tendon-actuated
robot, you can control-- you can start to route a
tendon all the way through it.

So if you imagine, like the
HOD Lipson example previously, maybe you could say, OK,
we can move a tendon here,

we can do that in there. That's not a problem
that I've solved, but I think it would be
really interesting to try to optimize on that.

But as you can imagine, if
you were to individually have control over
each one, then you would have to route to each one.

If you're in the bulk,
that might be difficult. A little bit similar-- but
when we're talking about the connection points and where
you're aligning the different

parts, I guess, when
they connect in, I guess, a given way, I'm assuming you
pick a given set of connection

points for each
of those shapes-- but is there, I
guess, a way to do

on the fly reconfiguration
of where those connection points occur? Or is it set when you do the
tendon structure, I guess?

Yeah, that's a
really good question. And I that's one of the
very fundamental principles in looking at
intra-reconfigurable

versus intra-reconfigurable
structures is that if you want
to attach and detach,

then you have to make a locking
mechanism in order to do that. So in the generative design--
if you're at design time and you-- let's
say, you don't want

to make this locking mechanism. Oh, it's too complicated to
make the locking mechanism. We're just going to
focus on design time.

We basically just
have a grammar that's eight different options of
ways that it can connect. And then you can apply one of
those parts of the grammar.

But if you're at design-- if
you're trying to cause something to attach together on
the fly then-- at least

in these designs, they don't
have an automatic way to do it, rather than actuating
it individually.

Yeah, I have questions about-- I'm curious if those soft
robotics, take some medicine

and then help them
to cure the disease.

Oh, yeah. I don't know if you're
familiar with your daily gels, but as far as-- I don't want to speak for
the lab, but what I heard

recently is that they were able
to do some tests with a pig and be able to deliver
medicine using a six hexagon

version of the kesling unit
in order to magnetically go through the pig. So, yeah, I'm really excited
to see if that project will

have some good results. Yeah. One question-- so
assume if there's a perfect locking mechanism,
a reconfiguration strategy,

is it possible to have basically
one cube that turns or converted

into any title or again, use? I think, on a theoretical
basis, then you can say,

OK, we're just going to put
as many different creases into it as we want.

But one challenge
with that is, I guess, one on the manufacturing
standpoint, it's the more creases
you add, the more

like-- especially
if you're doing a rigid in a flexible
manufacturing method, it just makes it--
more things can

break because each
hinge is a liability. But then also, we just
want to be able to-- I think one mode
of operation here

is to try to design the
simplest crease pattern that's possible to do a
specific application and not add additional-- try
to do it with as few creases as
possible.

So last year at the seminar
we had Cynthia Sung talk. Oh, yes. And I'm trying to integrate what
I've just learned from you today

with what she showed and has
shown her work on optimizations. It seems like you
restrict yourself

to the origami cube as
your basic primitive, but then you do a much wider
range of modifications to it.

And I think she's gone
